questions.text: A 70-year-old male with a history of long-standing myopia and open-angle glaucoma presents with a Goldmann visual field documenting the defect depicted in the Image to the I4e copter in the right eye. When he returns with a deteriorated visual field one year later, the most likely form of deterioration is?

options.label: D
options.text: Encroachment of the defect toward fixation

questions.correct_answer: D. Encroachment of the defect toward fixation
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Encroachment of the defect toward fixation The Image shows the presence of a superior nasal step defect. Visual field defects seen in cases of glaucoma are shown in the image below: Areas of the retina and/or optic nerve damaged by glaucoma are believed to be more vulnerable to ongoing damage at lower intraocular pressures (IOP) , thereby, field defects tend to become more severe with time. New defects also may appear, of course, but generally accompany the progression of previous defects.

Highyeild:

Abnormalities in the visual field are a sign of damage anywhere in the visual system from the retina through to the brain’s visual cortex. Visual field defects are, therefore, not limited to glaucoma. It is very important to examine the retina and optic disc carefully to assess whether or not a visual field defect matches the appearance of the disc and retina, or fits with other clinical signs.

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options A, B, and C are shown below -

Extraedge:

One should be very wary of a person with extensive field loss, which seems genuine, where examination of the retina and optic disc is normal. Early glaucomatous visual field defects are subtle and easily missed. Even with modern automated and sensitive visual field analyzers, glaucomatous visual field loss is not evident until at least 30% of the retinal ganglion cell axons that make up the optic nerve have been lost.

questions.text: A 59-year-old female presents with central field defects in the presence of a relatively normal peripheral field. Previous medical history is significant for the presence of myopia and long-standing hypertension. The exam findings are shown in the Images below. What is correct about this case

options.label: A
options.text: Optic disc examination for this disease should be performed with the pupils undilated

options.label: B
options.text: Optic disc size is a diagnostic indicator

options.label: C
options.text: Imaging can objectively measure disc area, but the horizontal diameter is the parameter most frequently used clinically

options.label: D
options.text: In some patients, even in the presence of substantial damage, the size of the cup may still be smaller than that of a large physiological cup.

questions.correct_answer: D. In some patients, even in the presence of substantial damage, the size of the cup may still be smaller than that of a large physiological cup.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

In some patients, even in the presence of substantial damage, the size of the cup may still be smaller than that of a large physiological cup. The given case history and findings point towards the diagnosis of glaucomatous optic neuropathy. Refractive status, as myopia, carries an increased risk of POAG and hypermetropia of primary angle-closure glaucoma (PACG). Myopic disc with glaucoma as seen in the 1st Image refers to a tilted (obliquely inserted), shallow disc with a temporal crescent of parapapillary atrophy , together with features of glaucomatous damage. Optic disc hemorrhage can be seen in the 2nd Image.

Highyeild:

An optic disc hemorrhage is a risk factor for the development and progression of glaucoma and can be missed unless magnification is used to examine the disc. Pathological cupping is caused by an irreversible decrease in the number of nerve fibers, glial cells, and blood vessels. A documented increase in cup size is always significant.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A . Optic disc examination for glaucomatous changes should be performed with the pupils dilated, provided the gonioscopy does not show critically narrow angles. Red-free light can be used to detect RNFL (Retinal Nerve Fiber Layer) defects. Option: B . Optic disc size is important in deciding if a C/D ratio is normal and is also a prognostic indicator . Large discs are believed to be more likely to sustain damage. Option: C . Imaging can objectively measure disc area, but the vertical diameter is the parameter most frequently used clinically. Normal median vertical diameter (for non-glaucomatous discs) is 1.5–1.7 mm

Extraedge:

If an eye with a small optic disc and a correspondingly small cup develops glaucoma, the cup will increase in size, but even in the presence of substantial damage may still be smaller than that of a large physiological cup .

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman comes to the physician for evaluation of diminished vision for several months. Twenty-eight years ago, she was diagnosed with systemic lupus erythematosus, which has been well controlled with hydroxychloroquine. Fundoscopic examination shows concentric rings of hypopigmentation and hyperpigmentation surrounding the fovea bilaterally. Visual field examination of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Paracentral scotoma The concentric rings of hypopigmentation and hyperpigmentation ("bull's eye maculopathy") are adverse effects of hydroxychloroquine therapy . Hydroxychloroquine maculopathy specifically targets the macular rods and cones but spares these same structures within the fovea.

Highyeild:

Paracentral scotoma describes an off-center area of visual loss surrounded by normal acuity in the rest of the visual field. As in this case, patients often report difficulty with tasks involving fine visual skills, such as reading, as well as visual color deficits.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Monocular blindness describes a total vision loss in one eye that can be caused by ischemia of the vessels supplying the retina, retinal vein occlusion, optic nerve compression, or optic nerve neuropathy. Treatment with hydroxychloroquine, however, is not associated with such a complication. Option: C. Hemianopia with macular sparing is a form of homonymous hemianopia in which the central visual field is spared. The visual cortex receives a dual blood supply from the posterior cerebral artery (supplies the anterior visual cortex, which processes peripheral vision) and the deep branch of the middle cerebral artery (supplies the occipital pole, which processes information from the central visual field). Infarcts of the PCA would therefore lead to hemianopia with macular sparing. Hydroxychloroquine , in contrast, may specifically damage the macula. Option: D. Bitemporal hemianopia describes the loss of vision in the outer halves of the visual field of both eyes. It is typically caused by a compression of the central region of the optic chiasm due to midline pathologies such as aneurysms, pituitary masses, or craniopharyngioma. Treatment with hydroxychloroquine, however, is associated with damage to the retina itself.

Extraedge:

Paracentral scotoma represents a more advanced stage of retinopathy and is an irreversible complication of hydroxychloroquine whose incidence increases with both the dose and the duration of treatment.

questions.text: The given defect is seen due to a lesion in:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Temporal lobe Visual field defects in the lesions of optic radiations vary depending upon the site of the lesion as below: Superior quadrantic hemianopia (pie in the sky is produced when inferior fibers are involved in temporal lobe lesions. Anatomically, it is explained by the fact that inferior fibers of optic radiations contain fibers from the ipsilateral lower temporal retina and contralateral lower nasal retina. Inferior fibers of optic radiation form the so-called Meyer's loop. Inferior quadrantic hemianopia (pie on the floor) is produced when superior fibers are involved in parietal lobe lesions . This is explained anatomically by the fact that superior fibers of optic radiations contain fibers from the ipsilateral upper temporal retina and contralateral nasal retina.

Highyeild:

questions.text: Third-year students were posted In the Ophthalmology department. The senior resident was explaining them the estimation of the visual field. All the following methods are used to estimate the visual field of the patient:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Optical coherence tomography Optical coherence tomography is not used to estimate the visual field. It is a non-invasive imaging technique to visualize cross-sections of the retina.

Highyeild:

Perimetry is used to estimate the visual field. Types: Manual perimetry- Confrontation method, Lister's perimeter, Campimetry (Scotometry), Goldmann's perimeter Automated perimetry- Octopus Fieldmaster, Humphrey Field Analyzer Other options – which are mentioned above are the types of Perimetry.

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Optic chiasma Bitemporal hemianopsia (or bitemporal hemianopia) describes the ocular defect that leads to impaired peripheral vision in the outer temporal halves of the visual field of each eye.

Highyeild:

This condition commonly results from a tumor or lesion impinging on the optic chiasm, the decussation point of the optic nerve conveying visual information from the nasal retina in each eye.

questions.text: A patient aged 45 years presents to the emergency department with redness of the right eye for 1 hour. He also complains of headaches and a diminution of vision. On examination, there is a vertically oval, mid-dilated pupil, and on fundoscopy, the optic disc is hyperaemic with a cup disc ratio of 0.6. Static perimetry was done. Which finding is considered a significant visual field loss in this disease?

options.label: A
options.text: Probability of <5% in corrected pattern standard deviation as confirmed on two consecutive tests.

options.label: C
options.text: Two contiguous, non-edge points on pattern deviation plot within Bjerrum’s area

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Both A and B On static perimetry , visual field loss in glaucoma is considered significant if one of the following is seen: The glaucoma hemifield test (GHT) is abnormal Three contiguous , non-edge points on the pattern deviation plot within Bjerrum’s area have a probability of < 5% of being seen in a normal population, one of which should have a probability of < 1% The corrected pattern standard deviation (CPSD) or PSD should have a probability of < 5%, confirmed on two consecutive tests.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: C. Three , and not two, contiguous, non-edge points on the pattern deviation plot within Bjerrum’s area are considered significant

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding the visual field changes seen in the glaucomatous eye?

options.label: A
options.text: Seidel’s scotoma starts at the poles of the blind spot

options.label: B
options.text: Central and temporal islands of vision are left in ring scotoma

options.label: C
options.text: Near total field defect has only a residual nasal field of vision

options.label: D
options.text: Smaller and dimmer targets are not visualized in relative paracentral scotomas

questions.correct_answer: C. Near total field defect has only a residual nasal field of vision
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Near total field defect has only a residual nasal field of vision End-stage or near-total field defect results when only a residual temporal island of vision is left and occurs at the last stage of the disease.

Highyeild:

Glaucomatous visual field defects are comprised of four major patterns : An isolated scotoma An arcuate scotoma A nasal step Generalized depression

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Seidel’s scotoma appears to start at the poles of the blind spot and arches over the macular area, without reaching the horizontal meridian nasally. Option: B . Double arcuate or ring scotoma is seen in advanced glaucomatous disease where only central and temporal islands of vision are left when two arcuate scotomas expand to involve the peripheral visual field. Option: D . Relative paracentral scotomas are areas where smaller or dimmer targets are not visualized by the patient, but larger or brighter targets are appreciated.

Extraedge:

Glaucoma progression was defined as a loss of >2dB in mean deviation confirmed in three consecutive visual field tests, or a persistent loss of two or more lines of vision -not attributable to non-glaucomatous causes in three consecutive follow-up examinations.

questions.text: A 37-year-old male patient presents with acute onset redness of the left eye along with a diminution of vision and severe headache. He has no history of similar complaints in the past. On examination, the pupil is vertically oval and mid-dilated along with a shallow anterior chamber and raised IOP. Perimetry shows Seidel’s scotoma. Which of the following correctly describes this visual defect?

options.label: A
options.text: Starts at the pole of the blind spot and arches over the macular area

options.label: B
options.text: Small, dim targets are not visualized as opposed to larger, brighter targets

options.label: C
options.text: Start at the superior or inferior poles of the blind spot and arch over the macular area

options.label: D
options.text: Horizontal shelf in the nasal visual field

questions.correct_answer: A. Starts at the pole of the blind spot and arches over the macular area
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Starts at the pole of the blind spot and arches over the macular area Seidel’s scotoma starts at the poles of the blind spot and arches over the macular area, without reaching the horizontal meridian nasally.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Paracentral scotomas are areas where smaller or dimmer targets are not visualized by the patient, but larger or brighter targets are appreciated. Option: C. Arcuate scotomas are similar to Seidel’s scotoma as they start at the superior or inferior poles of the blind spot and arch over the macular area, widening as they curve down or up, to end as a horizontal line nasally, which never crosses the horizontal division of the visual field. Option: D . The appearance of a horizontal shelf in the nasal visual field is called a nasal step and is caused by an asymmetry in nerve fiber loss at the two poles.
